1517335328_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
ublock and umatrix are requirements for a sane and useable internet.
https everywhere is a requirement.
some type of cookie auto-deleter is also necessary in the event you have to download cookies for a site to make it work.
decentraleyes is a cool idea, but doesn't have enough cdn content provided yet.
i don't think there is an extension or feature built into the browser yet that adequately protects users from deanonymization and tracking via canvas, that is probably the last thing i would need.

every other addon i have is just "nice" to have but not really necessary.

1517334612_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
i2p - my router runs 24/7 and seeds a few torrents over the network.
retroshare - a cool tool but rough around the edges and nobody i know/trust want to play with it.

1518871624_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
not utorrent, it seems!

i set up transmission-daemon on my home server a few years ago, and use transmission-remote from my laptop or desktop to control it. i have never taken the time to look into what other bitorrent clients have a similar feature, it's just the first thing i tried that worked. i don't think transmission is actively developed.

1518301564_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
when you plug in a magnet link, the first thing your bitorrent client has to do is download metadata that is already present in a .torrent file, such as the list of files, and the file sizes.

i also believe, but may be wrong, that .torrent files can contain other types of data, such as the username of the person on the private site who requested the file. on a private tracker, this would be useful because it deters people from sharing the .torrent file with others. i don't know exactly how private trackers ensure that only members of their site can download a given torrent so this could be wrong, i have never been an active member of any private tracker sites.

1521022489_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: firefox's rss handler does not notify you when there are changes in a site. rss works, and you can view entries to a feed from bookmarks, however, when a new entry to an rss feed is found, there are no notifications to alert you of it. it will just silently appear in the feed. for notifications, you will need to find a good addon.

1532691444_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: because  consumers download, and upload very little. "small business" internet plans tend to be the opposite, where there is much higher upload bandwidth, because that's what businesses do rather than download. if you call your isp and ask for more upload, they will likely offer you this business plan. from what i  hear, some places will just swap your home internet's download and upload speeds to increase it, which is a good tradeoff for upload heavy internet users.

1533555669_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
i'm a very private person by nature, so i have an inherent fear and disapproval of anyone collecting any information about me. additionally i just think its wrong to collect this information about people without their affirmative knowledge and consent.

maybe this is something that does not concern you. but it looks as though google has a lot of control over what appears to you when you look at your screen. you might be concerned that they will use this information to shape your behavior, choose which news articles it wants you to read, influence what kinds of books and movies you read, and help you decide what political beliefs you hold.

if it does not concern you that it does this to you, or you believe your are too strong or smart to succumb to their influence, then you might be concerned that they have the power to do this on a grandiose scale. google might not be able to influence YOUR vote, but it might be able to influence the votes of many of your neighbors and peers.

it might also concern you that it is not only google can do this, but several major tech companies, especially apple and microsoft, have this power over society.

1551542405_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
simply having a 24/7 connected router is beneficial to the network. being firewalled might put a damper on that, but it's probably fine. you don't need to visit sites or anything to help the network.

really, the best way to help right now is probably to leave the router running, and just participate in the community. the irc is a good place to see activity.

if your router can stay on 24/7, consider running a personal site. i2p comes prebundled with jetty and all you have to do is put your website there and turn your web server on (and tick it so it auto starts when you start up i2p). you can register a domain for it, or else people can just connect to it using the b32 address.

1581689103_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
the notion of having to go through a middleman to secure a deal with Bing is plausible.

evading questions related to System1's ownership of Waterfox remains a big red flag. "Not relevant, I'm still in involved in all my capacity, which is what matters." Either he is playing dumb, or is actually dumb and didn't consult with a lawyer on what ownership means.

i guess i'll have to go back to using palememe...

1582105711_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: dd is pure and beautiful and good. there was that one time once where i almost wrote over my windows partition with empty space. the gods were smiling upon me that day because i forgot to sudo. dd is the best.
